article:
There was one way I relaxed: smoking. Smoking was my addiction. I was a nurse. I   _  cigarettes
were slowly killing me.  _  I just couldn't stop.
As it was, I was running out of    _  to enjoy a cigarette. At home I had to go out on the
deck  to light up. One night, I    _  an uncontrolled cough. "Are you okay?" my husband
asked. I  _  to catch my breath. "Fine," I insisted.
But after weeks with a more    _  cough, I felt more foolish than ever. "I know, I
know," I told my husband  _  I came in from the deck one
night. "I want to quit. I'll try after this pack's finished. I promise."
I    _  to see
the day come, but I'd promised. I grabbed the empty pack and threw it away the
next  _  before work. Within an hour my head buzzed . Then came a full-on   _  . I shouted at co-workers, not knowing what to do with my  _  . Soon as my shift was over, I raced to the store. I tried other ways of quitting. But    _  worked. I went into my car. I started the engine, reached for my  _  and found there was none left!
I made it through the evening and went to bed early, just to be    _  . The next morning I  jumped out of  bed and had my coffee, as usual--- but not out on the deck with a
cigarette. My husband didn't know what to make of it.  At work  someone
asked me why I wasn't dying for a break. It was mid-afternoon. It struck me
that I hadn't smoked a cigarette all day. No one was more  _  than I was. My family  _  me when I said this time quitting was for
good.
They say the first couple of weeks are the    _  . I worked more than usual to  _  my
hands busy, but I've never been tempted to light up ever since.
